Buttons

A button indicates a possible user action. Apollo buttons feature clean, crisp edges. The rectangular button conveys Apollo's precise and efficient qualities. The floating nature of the hover state gives focus to the task. The reverb click animation gives users visual feedback in an Apollo way.

Button tags

Use the button classes on a <button>, <a>, or <input> element. If an <a> element is used to act as a button — triggering in-page functionality, rather than navigating to another document or section within the current page — it should also be given an appropriate role="button". As a best practice, we highly recommend using the <button> element whenever possible to ensure matching cross-browser rendering.

Link

Options

Primary buttons are used to indicate a call to action, while secondary buttons present an alternative action. Link style buttons are useful for vertically aligning a link that is adjacent to a primary or secondary button.

Disabled styling

When actions are disabled, you can apply disabled styling using the disabled attribute. For elements like <a> that don't support the disabled attribute, you can use the .disabled class instead.

Cancel

Sizes

Large and small size options are available to use. A large button works well for a prominent call to action, while small buttons are suited for use inside a table where space is limited. Block-level buttons are full-width and can be combined with small or large button styles.

Full-width

Button with icon

Icons can be added to buttons by placing them inside the tag, either alone or alongside the button label. Only buttons that use <button> or <a> tags can handle icons.

Icon only
Icon with label
